marc:datafield.marc:subfield: Written by Thomas Eddy's father, Pelig Eddy, with a note added by his sister, Mary Eddy. Contains news about their family and mutual acquaintances in Providence, Rhode Island and expresses concern for Eddy's health. Apparently, Eddy was on business in North Carolina.
Items dealing with the disposition of enslaved persons belonging to the estate of Pryant Easley.
Routine letters to Eaton as United States secretary of war, making recommendations for appointments.
A letter of March 21, 1831 from William Eaton to James Thorne about "the late war," presumably the War of 1812.
Ralph E. W. Earl was a portrait artist and "court painter" to Andrew Jackson and his family. He was the son of Ralph Earl (1751-1801), a well-known Revolutionary War-period artist.
Collection includes miscellaneous notes to Earl, a portraitist, concerning Washington society during the Jackson administration and a printed pen-and-ink sketch (self-portrait?) of Earl.

Mostly letters from former student Carrie McCord who moved with her family to Brazil in 1881. The letters discuss Brazilian social life and customs; Catholicism; the cities of Bahia and Rio de Janeiro; floods and landslides in Campos; smallpox in that city in 1882 and 1883; and the visit of the Emperor and Empress to celebrate bringing electricity there.
Letter of recommendation for Colonel Birch of Missouri for a governmental post in Washington by William T. Dyer, chairman of the Tippecanoe Club of Howard County.
Letter of Earle trying to identify Michel Ney, Marshal of France, as one Michael Rudolph, Revolutionary War veteran of Elkton, Maryland.
U.S. Army officer, lawyer, Confederate general, and president of the Southern Historical Society, from Virginia.

Miscellaneous letters and papers including a few items of routine military correspondence from the Civil War; comments on Reconstruction; mention of the problems confronting the Southern Historical Society; items dealing with railroad building; and Early's criticism of biographical sketches of himself.
Union soldier and farmer, from Carbondale (Jackson Co.), Ill.

Letters of Easterly and various members of his family concerning the problems of managing the farm while Easterly was in the United States Army during the Civil War; Northern and Southern views of Reconstruction; and family matters.
Personal letter from W. J. H. Durham, a student at Jefferson Medical College in Philadelphia, to his brother concerning family matters.

Civil War letters of the four Durfee brothers, John B. and Benjamin of the 9th Regiment, Rhode Island Volunteers, a ninety-day organization; A.Y., stationed off Pensacola, Fla., aboard the Mississippi; and William H., Jr., of the 5th Regiment, Rhode Island Volunteers, and a prisoner at the military prison at Charleston, S.C.
Letter, 1861 May 23, discontinuing a subscription to the Home Journal because of its abolitionist proclivities.
Union soldier, probably a member of the 3rd Wisconsin Infantry Regiment; from [Fond du Lac County], Wis.
Diary recording daily activities and camp life during the Civil War.

Personal correspondence of Z.T. Durham, with Brantley A. Denmark and Arthur Howell of Savannah, Ga., reflecting the difficulties of Reconstruction, and including a letter describing Southern feelings about the Fourth of July. A letter, 1872, by Durham, describes Texas, and a letter, 1874, from John Snyder in San Francisco, describes that city and other parts of the West.
Business notes, signed in Lexington, Virginia.
Farmer, of North Hamilton (Clarke Co.), Ohio, and Sperryville (Rappahannock Co.), Va.
Personal letters concerning crops, sickness, and family matters in Ohio and Virginia.
Circulars sent out to stockholders relating to the reorganization of the company.
